stem: The pediatric nurse is assessing the development of three different children during well-child visits. Based on the documented physical and cognitive findings, match each developmental milestone to the most appropriate age group.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient 1 (Ava): Parent reports she is now sitting up without help and loves to 'rake' her Cheerios toward her with her whole hand. She has started babbling 'ba-ba'. 
Patient 2 (Liam): Liam is now walking while holding on to furniture (cruising) and can pick up a small Cheerio using his thumb and forefinger (neat pincer). He says 'Mama' and 'Dada' specifically. 
Patient 3 (Chloe): Chloe is now walking independently and can climb stairs with one hand held. She can use a spoon and has a vocabulary of about 15-20 words.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
Ava: Moro reflex gone. Sits unsupported. Palmar grasp reflex gone. 
Liam: Birth weight tripled. Posterior fontanelle closed. Standing alone for 2 seconds. 
Chloe: Anterior fontanelle closing/closed. Can build a tower of 3-4 blocks. Runs clumsily.

rows.text: Sitting unsupported and using a 'raking' palmar grasp
Walking while holding furniture (cruising) and using a neat pincer grasp
Climbing stairs and using a spoon independently
Vocabulary of 10-25 words and running clumsily

rationale.correct: At **6 months**, infants should sit unsupported and use a raking grasp. By **12 months**, they should triple their birth weight, cruise, and have a neat pincer grasp. By **18 months**, toddlers should be walking well, climbing stairs, using a spoon, and have a vocabulary of at least 10 words. Chloe (Patient 3) is a classic 18-month-old, Liam (Patient 2) is a 12-month-old, and Ava (Patient 1) is a 6-month-old.
clinicalPearls: The 'neat pincer grasp' (thumb and forefinger) is a critical 10-12 month milestone.
The anterior fontanelle usually closes between 12-18 months.
Birth weight doubles at 6 months and triples at 12 months.

questionTrap.trap: Confusing the 'raking grasp' (6 mo) with the 'pincer grasp' (12 mo).
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that fine motor control moves from the whole hand (proximal) to the fingertips (distal) over the first year.

mnemonic.title: Pediatric Motor
mnemonic.expansion: 6 Mo: Sit (Six/Sit). 12 Mo: Stand (Twelve/Tall). 18 Mo: Steps (Eighteen/Escalator/Stairs).
